title: 1  Why Rebuild Valuation?
text:
Thesis. Valuation is capital allocation under uncertainty. Traditional DCF treats cash flows and the discount rate as exogenous inputs. The Investment CAPM (production-based asset pricing) derives both from the firm’s optimal investment policy under technology and adjustment costs.
What this book does.

Replace ad-hoc DCF components with a structural production model.
Show that expected returns (risk premia) are tied to investment and profitability.
Build practical workflows for investors and risk managers.

title: 2  DCF vs. Investment CAPM
text:
2.0.1 The two identities
Traditional DCF \[
V_0=\sum_{t\ge1}\frac{E[CF_t]}{(1+r)^t}
\]
Cash flows and (r) are assumptions.
Investment CAPM (structural valuation) \[
V_0=E_0\sum_{t\ge1}\frac{\pi(K_t,I_t^*)-\Phi(I_t^*,K_t)}{\prod_{s=1}^t (1+R_s)}
\]
where (I_t^*) solves the firm’s production problem and (R_s) follows from the pricing condition (Euler equation).


2.0.2 The firm’s problem (preview)
\[
\max_{\{I_t\}} E_0 \sum_{t\ge0} \frac{\pi(K_t,I_t) - \Phi(I_t,K_t)}{\prod_{s=1}^t(1+R_s)}
\quad \text{s.t. } K_{t+1}=(1-\delta)K_t+I_t
\]

((K,I)): operating profits from capital and investment.
((I,K)): convex adjustment costs (irreversibility, ramp-up frictions).
Decision variable: investment.
